This weekend, the White House is denying reports that President Bush had lost confidence in CIA director Porter Goss.

One of the Washington reporters trying to solve this mystery is Walter Pincus of The Washington Post, and he joins me now.
In your Post story today, you quote unnamed Administration officials as saying the President did lose confidence in Porter Goss.
What did your sources say about why he lost confidence?
Well, there are a whole series of things.

He was really sent over to clear out what the White House saw was an intelligence agency at the top that was leaking information, it was undermining the Administration's position, not just on weapons of mass destruction looking backwards, but also the way the war was running, and particularly leaks that took place just prior to the 2004 election.
He also went over with a sort of mandate to follow through on some of the findings of the early investigations about the failures before 9-11 and WMD.
But he took with him a group of staff people who were from the Republican staff for the House Intelligence Committee, which he chaired, and they were former CIA people.
And they started cleaning house, as the rumors went, with the people who didn't promote them when they were still there.

The house cleaning that took place went way beyond that.
It began to go into the senior part of the agency and therefore you lost a lot of seasoned people that you needed to keep.
